Award.AwardTitle: Travel Support for an ACS PMSE Symposium Entitled "Hairy Particles: Theory, Synthesis, Behavior, and Applications", September 8-12, 2013, Indianapolis, IN
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal requests funding in support of the domestic travel of participants to a symposium: "Hairy Particles: Theory, Synthesis, Behavior, and Applications", to be held at the ACS National Meeting Sept 8-12, 2013. Hairy particles are composed of a core, either inorganic, metallic, or polymeric, and a layer of polymer chains densely grafted by one end via a covalent bond on the surface of the core (i.e. polymer brushes).

The diverse potential applications of the hairy particles range from advanced composites to catalysis and sensing. The organizers (Profs. Zhao,Zhu,Li) bring a broad range of expertise in polymer chemistry and polymer physics pertinent to the symposium topic.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Hairy particles are composed of an inorganic or metallic core and a layer of polymer chains densely grafted by one end via a convalent bond on the surface of the core (i.e., polymer brushes). These particles are an intriguing class of nanostructured organic-inorganic hybrid materials with great potential in a variety of applications including advanced nanocomposite materials, catalysis, energy conversion and storage. With the support of Award NSF-1322184 and American Chemical Society (ACS), we (Christopher Y. Li of Drexel University, Lei Zhu of Case Western Reserve University, and Bin Zhao of University of Tennessee Knoxville) organized a two-day symposium on "Hairy Particles: Theory, Synthesis, Behavior, and Applications" on September 8-9, 2013 at the 2013 Fall ACS National Meeting in Indianapolis, IN. The symposium, consisting of 28 oral presentations and a number of poster presentations, showcased the most recent achievements and new developments in the area of hairy particles. The symposium was well attended with average audience per session of around 50. The participants were from the US, Canada, Japan, and China, including two assistant professors and female professors. The requested $4,000 NSF money and the ACS funds were used to partially compensate the travel expenses of invited speakers.

The symposium provided a forum for assistant professors, postdoctoral researchers, and graduate students to present their research results at the professional conference, helping them to develop their careers. On the basis of the symposium, we edited a special issue on "Hairy Particles: Theory, Synthesis, Behavior, and Applications" for Journal of Polymer Science, Part B: Polymer Physics, which will be published in December, 2014. The ACS symposium and the special issue help the societal awareness of the great potential of hairy particles in a variety of applications.
